general context
- Language: Czech (Majka morphological analyzer tagset; also used for Slovak in some corpora, but this corpus is Czech).
- Basic token-level attributes:
  - word – surface word form
  - tag – full morphological tag (Majka “attributive” tagset)
  - lempos – lemma with POS suffix (e.g. dům-n)
  - gender_lemma – lemma enriched with gender info
  - lc – word in lowercase
  - lempos_lc – lempos in lowercase
  - lemma – lemma without POS
  - lemma_lc – lemma in lowercase
  - gender_lemma_lc – gender_lemma in lowercase
  - k, g, n, c, p, m, pos – technical attributes mirroring particular parts of the tag (e.g. POS, gender, number, case, person, verb form); use only if you know the corpus-specific mapping.
- Structural elements:
  - g – group-level structure (e.g. paragraph group; exact function corpus-specific)
  - s – sentence
  - p – paragraph; attribute:
    - heading – paragraph heading
  - doc – document; attributes:
    - url – document URL
    - title – document title
    - wiki_categories – Wikipedia categories
    - urldomain – full domain (e.g. news.blogs.cnn.com)
    - website – base site (e.g. cnn.com)
    - crawl_date – full crawl date
    - modified_date – full modified date
    - wiki_translations – Wikipedia translations
    - modified_month – month of modification
    - tld – top-level domain (e.g. com)
    - modified_year – year of modification
    - topic – topic label
    - domain_distance – distance from seed domains
    - genre – text genre
    - src – source label
    - crawl_year – crawl year

- Lempos POS suffixes (attribute lempos / lempos_lc):
  - -n – noun
  - -j – adjective
  - -d – pronoun
  - -m – numeral
  - -v – verb
  - -a – adverb
  - -p – preposition
  - -c – conjunction

- Named POS annotations (primarily for internal/word sketch use; logically equal to these tag regexes):
  - noun = tag "k1.*"
  - adjective = tag "k2.*"
  - pronoun = tag "k3.*"
  - numeral = tag "k4.*"
  - verb = tag "k5.*"
  - adverb = tag "k6.*"
  - preposition = tag "k7.*"
  - conjunction = tag "k8.*"

- Available word sketch relations (grammatical/lexical relations used by Sketch Engine for this tagset; “%w” stands for the node word):
  - "%w" and/or ...
  - "%w" is ...
  - "%w" of ...
  - ... is "%w"
  - ... of "%w"
  - accusative objects of "%w"
  - dative objects of "%w"
  - genitive objects of "%w"
  - infinitive objects of "%w"
  - instrumental objects of "%w"
  - locale objects of "%w"
  - modified by "%w"
  - modifiers of "%w"
  - nouns after "%w"
  - nouns before "%w"
  - nouns modified by "%w"
  - nouns or verbs after "%w"
  - nouns or verbs before "%w"
  - numbers before "%w"
  - passive verbs with "%w" as subject
  - prepositional phrases
  - subjects of "%w"
  - subjects of "be %w"
  - subjects of passive "%w"
  - verbs before "%w"
  - verbs with "%w" as accusative object
  - verbs with "%w" as dative object
  - verbs with "%w" as genitive object
  - verbs with "%w" as infinitive object
  - verbs with "%w" as instrumental object
  - verbs with "%w" as locale object
  - verbs with "%w" as subject
  - words after "%w"
  - words before "%w"


how CQL with tagset should be written
- The tag attribute stores one compact string per token that encodes POS and all available morphological features.
- Tag format is strict: it must follow this canonical attribute order:
  k e g n c p a m d x y t z w ~
  (k = POS, e = negation, g = gender, n = number, c = case, p = person, a = aspect, m = verb form/mood, d = degree, x/y/t/z = subtypes/other features, w = stylistic flag, ~ = other/rare features).
- Each part of the tag is encoded as:
  - one lowercase attribute code (k, e, g, n, c, p, a, m, d, x, y, t, z, w, ~)
  - immediately followed by one uppercase (or symbol) value character (e.g. gF, nP, c7).
- Attributes, if present, must appear in this exact order; you cannot permute them. Missing attributes are simply omitted, but you must not place a later attribute before an earlier one.
  - Example (correct): k2gFnSc7... (gender g before number n before case c)
  - Example (incorrect): k2nSgFc7... (number before gender – wrong order; will not match the real tags).
- Tag is a single contiguous string with no separators between attribute–value pairs.
- Always use straight double quotes in CQL (") for attribute values, not typographic quotes.

- Basic CQL patterns with this tagset:
  - All verbs: [tag="k5.*"]
  - All nouns: [tag="k1.*"]
  - All plural numerals: [tag="k4.*nP.*"]
  - All neuter nouns: [tag="k1gN.*"]
  - All masculine nouns (animate or inanimate): [tag="k1g(M|I).*"]
  - Feminine singular adjectives in instrumental: [tag="k2gFnSc7.*"]
  - All comparative adjectives: [tag="k2.*d2.*"]
  - All verbs in negative form and feminine: [tag="k5eNgF.*"]
  - All instrumental plural adjectives: [tag="k2.*nPc7.*"]

- Attribute-based searches (examples for key token attributes):
  - word form: [word="dům"] or [lc="dům"]
  - lemma: [lemma="dům"] or [lemma_lc="dům"]
  - lempos: [lempos="dům-n"] or any noun lemma: [lempos=".*-n"]
  - POS by lempos suffix: nouns [lempos=".*-n"], verbs [lempos=".*-v"], adjectives [lempos=".*-j"], etc.
- You can combine attributes and regular expressions:
  - Noun lemma “dům” in plural: [lemma="dům" & tag="k1.*nP.*"]
  - Any verb lemma ending -ovat in past participle: [lempos=".*ovat-v" & tag="k5.*mA.*"]

- Structural CQL examples:
  - Limit to sentences: within <s/>: <s> []{0,10} </s>
  - Restrict to specific genre: within <doc genre="news"> ... </doc>
  - Filter by domain or year at document level:
    - <doc urldomain="news.blogs.cnn.com"> ... </doc>
    - <doc crawl_year="2018"> ... </doc>


the tagset
(Each line: attribute code – meaning – values and their meanings.)

k – part of speech (first 2 characters of tag) – values:
  k1 noun
  k2 adjective
  k3 pronoun
  k4 number (numeral)
  k5 verb
  k6 adverb
  k7 preposition
  k8 conjunction
  k9 particle
  k0 interjection
  kA abbreviation
  kI punctuation

e – negation (adjectives, verbs, adverbs) – values:
  eA affirmation (non-negative form)
  eN negation

g – gender (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals) – values:
  gM animate masculine
  gI inanimate masculine
  gN neuter
  gF feminine
  gR family/surname gender (e.g. Havlovi)

p – person (pronouns, verbs) – values:
  p1 first person
  p2 second person
  p3 third person

n – number (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals) – values:
  nS singular
  nP plural

c – case (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals, prepositions) – values:
  c1 nominative
  c2 genitive
  c3 dative
  c4 accusative
  c5 vocative
  c6 locative
  c7 instrumental
  (for prepositions, c1–c4, c6, c7 represent the governed case)

d – degree (adjectives, adverbs) – values:
  d1 positive
  d2 comparative
  d3 superlative

w – stylistic flag (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals, verbs, adverbs, prepositions, conjunctions, particles) – values:
  wA archaism
  wB poeticism
  wC only in corpora
  wE expressive
  wH conversational
  wK bookish
  wO regional
  wR rare
  wZ obsolete
  wN dialectal

x – subtype 1 (varies by POS) – main documented values:
  (noun k1)
    xP special paradigm (e.g. půl, čtvrt)
  (pronoun k3)
    xP personal pronoun
    xO possessive pronoun
    xD demonstrative pronoun
    xT delimitative pronoun
  (number k4)
    xC cardinal numeral
    xO ordinal numeral
    xR reproductive numeral
  (adverb k6)
    xD demonstrative adverb
    xT delimitative adverb
  (conjunction k8)
    xC coordinate conjunction
    xS subordinate conjunction
  (punctuation kI)
    x. punctuation: .?!
    x, punctuation: ,:;
    x" punctuation: “„‚"
    x( punctuation: ({[<
    x) punctuation: )}]>
    x~ other punctuation/symbols: ~$%^&-_+=|/# etc.

y – subtype 2 (varies by POS; often interrogative/relative/negative etc.) – values:
  yF reflexive pronoun
  yQ interrogative (pronoun or adverb)
  yR relative (pronoun or adverb)
  yN negative (pronoun, numeral, adverb)
  yI indeterminate (pronoun, numeral, adverb)

a – aspect (verbs k5) – values:
  aP perfective
  aI imperfective
  aB biaspectual

m – verbal form / mood (verbs k5) – values:
  mF infinitive
  mI present indicative
  mR imperative
  mA past participle (active participle)
  mN passive participle (n/t-participle)
  mS present transgressive
  mD past transgressive
  mB future indicative

t – semantic/type feature for adverbs (k6) – values:
  tS status adverb
  tD modal adverb
  tT time adverb
  tA respect adverb
  tC reason adverb
  tL place adverb
  tM manner adverb
  tQ extent adverb

z – additional/misc feature slot – used in some complex tags; individual values not fully documented here.

~ – extra feature slot – used in very complex/derived tags; individual values not fully documented here.

(Other complex features such as rD or hX combinations in the “Further tag features” table exist but are specialized and rarely needed for ordinary CQL; if you must match them, treat them as literal substrings within tag, respecting the same canonical order rules.)

. - You can combine structural and token conditions: - [tag="k5.*"] (verbs in chapter 1). Strict tag format and order (critical for CQL) - Full tag is a single string consisting ONLY of concatenated attribute–value pairs, no separators. - The canonical order of attributes in every tag is strictly: k e g n c p a m d x y t z w ~ - “Strict” means: - If an attribute appears, it must follow this exact order relative to others. - You must NOT change the order in CQL patterns; regex must respect the canonical order. - You may omit attributes (they simply do not appear in the tag), but you cannot reorder them. - Examples: - Correct: [tag="k1gN.*"] – PoS noun (k1), gender neuter (gN). - Correct: [tag="k2.*gFnSc7.*"] – adjective (k2), feminine (gF), singular (nS), instrumental case (c7). - Incorrect: [tag="k2.*nSgFc7.*"] – number (n) is written before gender (g) in the pattern; this violates the canonical order and will not work as intended. Typical CQL patterns with this tagset - All nouns: [tag="k1.*"] - All adjectives: [tag="k2.*"] - All pronouns: [tag="k3.*"] - All numerals: [tag="k4.*"] - All verbs: [tag="k5.*"] - All adverbs: [tag="k6.*"] - All prepositions: [tag="k7.*"] - All conjunctions: [tag="k8.*"] - All particles: [tag="k9.*"] or [tag="k9"] (the tag can be just k9). - All interjections: [tag="k0.*"] or [tag="k0"]. - All plural numerals: [tag="k4.*nP.*"] - All plural nouns: [tag="k1.*nP.*"] - All neuter nouns: [tag="k1gN.*"] - All masculine nouns: [tag="k1g(M|I).*"] - All instrumental plural adjectives: [tag="k2.*nPc7.*"] - All comparative adjectives: [tag="k2.*d2.*"] - All third-person pronouns: [tag="k3p3.*"] - All negative verbs (any gender): [tag="k5eN.*"] - All feminine negative verbs: [tag="k5eNgF.*"] Using lempos in CQL - lempos combines lemma with a PoS suffix: - Example noun: [lempos="dům-n"] - Example verb: [lempos="být-v"] - Example adjective (lowercase): [lempos_lc="dobrý-j"] - You can also use regex on lempos: - All verb lemmas: [lempos=".*-v"] - All noun lemmas: [lempos=".*-n"] Tag-based “annotations” (for filters / metadata) - Annotation noun: tag matches k1.* - Annotation adjective: tag matches k2.* - Annotation pronoun: tag matches k3.* - Annotation numeral: tag matches k4.* - Annotation verb: tag matches k5.* - Annotation adverb: tag matches k6.* - Annotation preposition: tag matches k7.* - Annotation conjunction: tag matches k8.* - Annotation particle: tag equals k9 - Annotation interjection: tag equals k0 THE TAGSET ========== Overall tag format - Each tag is a single, continuous string with no delimiters, made of attribute–value pairs. - PoS is always first, encoded by k + one character (0–9, A, I): k1, k2, ..., kI. - All other attributes are optional but, if present, must appear in the strict order: k e g n c p a m d x y t z w ~ - Part-of-speech codes, morphological categories, and values are case-sensitive. Canonical attribute sequence (each line = one part of tag) - k – Part of speech (major word class; e.g. k1, k2, k5, etc.). - e – Negation (applies to adjectives, verbs, adverbs). - g – Gender (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals). - n – Number (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals). - c – Case (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals, prepositions). - p – Person (pronouns, verbs). - a – Aspect (verbs). - m – Verb form / mood / tense / participle type (verbs). - d – Degree (adjectives, adverbs). - x – Subclassification type 1 (varies by PoS: nouns, pronouns, numerals, adverbs, conjunctions, punctuation). - y – Subclassification type 2 (varies by PoS: pronouns, numerals, adverbs). - t – Adverbial semantics (adverbs). - z – Additional (derivational or other) features (rare; includes rD-like chains). - w – Stylistic flag (register, status, etc.). - ~ – Other special features (rare; not elaborated in the documentation). Part of speech (attribute k – always first) - k1 – Part of speech: noun. - k2 – Part of speech: adjective. - k3 – Part of speech: pronoun. - k4 – Part of speech: numeral (number). - k5 – Part of speech: verb. - k6 – Part of speech: adverb. - k7 – Part of speech: preposition. - k8 – Part of speech: conjunction. - k9 – Part of speech: particle. - k0 – Part of speech: interjection. - kA – Part of speech: abbreviation. - kI – Part of speech: punctuation. Negation (attribute e – adjectives, verbs, adverbs) - eA – Negation: affirmation (non-negative form). - eN – Negation: negation (negative form). Gender (attribute g – nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals) - gM – Gender: animate masculine. - gI – Gender: inanimate masculine. - gN – Gender: neuter. - gF – Gender: feminine. - gR – Gender: family/surname gender (e.g. Havlovi). Person (attribute p – pronouns, verbs) - p1 – Person: first person. - p2 – Person: second person. - p3 – Person: third person. Number (attribute n – nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals) - nS – Number: singular. - nP – Number: plural. Case (attribute c – nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals, prepositions) - c1 – Case: nominative; for prepositions, “preposition with first case”. - c2 – Case: genitive; for prepositions, “preposition with second case”. - c3 – Case: dative; for prepositions, “preposition with third case”. - c4 – Case: accusative; for prepositions, “preposition with fourth case”. - c5 – Case: vocative (not used with prepositions). - c6 – Case: locative; for prepositions, “preposition with sixth case”. - c7 – Case: instrumental; for prepositions, “preposition with seventh case”. Aspect (attribute a – verbs) - aP – Aspect: perfective. - aI – Aspect: imperfective. - aB – Aspect: biaspectual (both aspects). Verb form / mood / tense / participle type (attribute m – verbs) - mF – Verb form: infinitive. - mI – Verb form: present indicative. - mR – Verb form: imperative. - mA – Verb form: past participle (active participle). - mN – Verb form: passive participle (n/t-participle). - mS – Verb form: present transgressive (present converb). - mD – Verb form: past transgressive (past converb). - mB – Verb form: future indicative. Degree (attribute d – adjectives, adverbs) - d1 – Degree: positive. - d2 – Degree: comparative. - d3 – Degree: superlative. Stylistic flag (attribute w – many PoS) - wA – Style: archaism. - wB – Style: poeticism. - wC – Style: only attested in corpora. - wE – Style: expressive. - wH – Style: conversational (colloquial). - wK – Style: bookish. - wN – Style: dialectal. - wO – Style: regional. - wR – Style: rare. - wZ – Style: obsolete. Noun subclassification (attribute x with k1) - xP – Noun special paradigm: “půl, čtvrt” and similar special-pattern nouns. Pronoun subclassification (attributes x and y with k3) - xP – Pronoun type (x): personal pronoun. - xO – Pronoun type (x): possessive pronoun. - xD – Pronoun type (x): demonstrative pronoun. - xT – Pronoun type (x): delimitative pronoun. - yF – Pronoun type (y): reflexive pronoun. - yQ – Pronoun type (y): interrogative pronoun. - yR – Pronoun type (y): relative pronoun. - yN – Pronoun type (y): negative pronoun. - yI – Pronoun type (y): indeterminate pronoun. Numeral subclassification (attributes x and y with k4) - xC – Numeral type (x): cardinal numeral. - xO – Numeral type (x): ordinal numeral. - xR – Numeral type (x): “reproductive” numeral (repeating/distributive type). - yN – Numeral type (y): negative numeral. - yI – Numeral type (y): indeterminate numeral. Verb additional features (beyond a, m) - (as above) aP, aI, aB specify aspect; mF, mI, mR, mA, mN, mS, mD, mB specify form. - Some tags may also include derivational/formation sequences (attribute z) such as rD (see “Further features” below), but these are rarely needed in normal CQL. Adverb subclassification (attributes x, y, t with k6) - xD – Adverb type (x): demonstrative adverb. - xT – Adverb type (x): delimitative adverb. - yQ – Adverb type (y): interrogative adverb. - yR – Adverb type (y): relative adverb. - yN – Adverb type (y): negative adverb. - yI – Adverb type (y): indeterminate adverb. - tS – Adverb semantics (t): status adverb. - tD – Adverb semantics (t): modal adverb. - tT – Adverb semantics (t): time adverb (expresses time). - tA – Adverb semantics (t): respect adverb (expresses respect/with regard to). - tC – Adverb semantics (t): reason adverb (expresses cause). - tL – Adverb semantics (t): place adverb (expresses location). - tM – Adverb semantics (t): manner adverb (expresses manner). - tQ – Adverb semantics (t): extent adverb (expresses extent). Conjunction subclassification (attribute x with k8) - xC – Conjunction type (x): coordinate conjunction. - xS – Conjunction type (x): subordinate conjunction. Punctuation subclassification (attribute x with kI) - x. – Punctuation: sentence-final (. ? !). - x, – Punctuation: separators (, : ;). - x" – Punctuation: quotation marks (" „ “ ‚ '). - x( – Punctuation: opening brackets ( { [ <. - x) – Punctuation: closing brackets ) } ] >. - x~ – Punctuation: other symbols (~ $ % ^ & - _ + = | / # etc.). Additional “further features” (rare, advanced; mostly attribute z or related) These are present in the documentation but rarely needed in standard CQL. They indicate derivational or possessive patterns and semantic roles: - rD – Derivational feature “INF : ADJ-ci / ADJ-ši / SUBST-i / ADJ-ý / ADJ-n//-t” (often repeated: rD,rD,...); multiple rD values in a row encode chains of derivation (infinitive → adjective → noun, etc.). - hF – Feature: feminine possessive noun (SUBST:FEMPOSS). - hM – Feature: masculine possessive noun (SUBST:MASKPOSS). - hR – Feature: family/“rodina” possessive tag. - hT – Feature: pronoun represents thing. - hP – Feature: pronoun represents person. (These h* and rD-type features appear as additional components inside the tag; when writing CQL, you can match them literally if needed, but they are specialized and not required for ordinary PoS/morph searches.) Summary of strictness of tag format - Tags must: - Begin with a valid PoS code (k0, k1, ..., k9, kA, kI). - Follow the fixed attribute order k e g n c p a m d x y t z w ~ without any reordering. - Use exactly the documented letter codes and capital letters (case-sensitive). - CQL patterns operating on tag must respect this exact format and order; otherwise, they will fail or return unintended matches.

----------------
- Language: Czech (tagset also used for some Slovak corpora via the Majka morphological analyzer).
- Morphology: “attributive” Czech POS tagset from Majka. Each tag is a concatenation of attribute–value pairs in a fixed canonical order.
- Canonical order of attributes in a tag:  
  `k e g n c p a m d x y t z w ~`  
  (k is always first; other attributes appear, if present, exactly in this order.)

how CQL with tagset should be written
-------------------------------------
- Tags are matched with the positional attribute `tag` using regular expressions:  
  Example: `[tag="k5.*"]` (all verbs).
- Always use straight double quotes `"..."` in CQL, not typographic quotes.
- Tag format is STRICT:  
  - A tag is a single uninterrupted string; no separators.  
  - It starts with the POS code `kX` (X is 0–9, A, I).  
  - After `kX`, it contains zero or more attribute–value pairs, each as a lowercase attribute letter plus an uppercase letter/digit value.  
  - Attributes, if present, must follow the canonical order: `k e g n c p a m d x y t z w ~`.  
  - You cannot change the order (`"k2.*gFnSc7.*"` is valid; `"k2.*nSgFc7.*"` is invalid).
- To ignore unspecified parts of the tag, use `.*` as a wildcard:  
  - All verbs: `[tag="k5.*"]`  
  - All plural numerals: `[tag="k4.*nP.*"]`
- Examples from documentation:
  - All plural nouns: `[tag="k1.*nP.*"]` (e.g. lidé, roky).
  - All neuter nouns: `[tag="k1gN.*"]`.
  - All masculine nouns: `[tag="k1g(M|I).*"]`.
  - All plural numbers: `[tag="k4.*nP.*"]`.
  - All instrumental plural adjectives: `[tag="k2.*nPc7.*"]`.
  - All comparative adjectives: `[tag="k2.*d2.*"]`.
  - All negative feminine verbs: `[tag="k5eNgF.*"]`.
- You can also constrain attributes via their separate positional attributes: e.g. `[g="F"]` (feminine), `[n="P"]` (plural), `[c="4"]` (accusative), etc., depending on how they are encoded in this specific corpus.
- Lempos in CQL:
  - Restrict by POS via lempos suffix, e.g. `[lempos=".*-v"]` (verbs), `[lempos=".*-n"]` (nouns).
  - Combine lemma and POS, e.g. `[lempos="být-v"]`, `[lempos_lc="praha-n"]`.
- Other token attributes:
  - Use `[word="..."]`/`[lc="..."]` for surface forms, `[lemma="..."]`/`[lemma_lc="..."]` for lemmas.
- Structural attributes in CQL:
  - Restrict queries by document fields, e.g.:  
    `within <doc date_year="2015">` or `within <doc chamber="...">`.  
  - Match or filter by speaker, paragraph, note type, etc.:  
    e.g. `within <speaker name=".*Opposition.*">`, `within <note type=".*">`.


the tagset
----------
GENERAL PRINCIPLE – TAG STRUCTURE  
Each tag is a concatenation of attribute–value pairs:

- k – part of speech (always first; values below)
- e – negation (where applicable)
- g – gender (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals)
- n – number (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals)
- c – case (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals, prepositions)
- p – person (pronouns, verbs)
- a – aspect (verbs)
- m – verb form / mood / tense (verbs)
- d – degree (adjectives, adverbs)
- x – subtype 1 (various POS-specific subclasses: nouns, pronouns, numerals, adverbs, conjunctions, punctuation)
- y – subtype 2 (mostly pronouns, numerals, adverbs)
- t – adverb semantic type (adverbs)
- z – attribute present in canonical order string but not documented here; treat any occurrences as part of tag and match literally or with `.*`
- w – stylistic flag (many POS)
- ~ – final technical/other flag present in canonical order string; details not documented; treat literally or with `.*` if it appears

EXPLAINING EACH DOCUMENTED ATTRIBUTE / VALUE (ONE LINE PER PART)

1. Part of speech: k
- k1 – noun  
- k2 – adjective  
- k3 – pronoun  
- k4 – numeral  
- k5 – verb  
- k6 – adverb  
- k7 – preposition  
- k8 – conjunction  
- k9 – particle  
- k0 – interjection  
- kA – abbreviation  
- kI – punctuation  

Example CQL: `[tag="k5.*"]` (all verbs).

2. Negation: e (adjectives, verbs, adverbs)
- eA – affirmation (non‑negative form)  
- eN – negation  

Example CQL: `[tag="k5eN.*"]` (all negated verbs).

3. Gender: g (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals)
- gM – animate masculine  
- gI – inanimate masculine  
- gN – neuter  
- gF – feminine  
- gR – family (surname) gender (e.g. Havlovi)  

Example CQL: `[tag="k1gN.*"]` (neuter nouns); `[tag="k1g(M|I).*"]` (masculine nouns).

4. Person: p (pronouns, verbs)
- p1 – first person  
- p2 – second person  
- p3 – third person  

Example CQL: `[tag="k3p3.*"]` (third-person pronouns).

5. Number: n (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals)
- nS – singular  
- nP – plural  

Example CQL: `[tag="k4.*nP.*"]` (plural numerals).

6. Case: c (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals, prepositions)
- c1 – nominative (or preposition governing 1st case)  
- c2 – genitive (or preposition governing 2nd case)  
- c3 – dative (or preposition governing 3rd case)  
- c4 – accusative (or preposition governing 4th case)  
- c5 – vocative  
- c6 – locative (or preposition governing 6th case)  
- c7 – instrumental (or preposition governing 7th case)  

Examples:  
- `[tag="k2.*nPc7.*"]` – plural instrumental adjectives.  
- For prepositions, values c1–c4,c6,c7 indicate the governed case.

7. Degree: d (adjectives, adverbs)
- d1 – positive degree  
- d2 – comparative  
- d3 – superlative  

Example CQL: `[tag="k2.*d2.*"]` (comparative adjectives).

8. Stylistic flag: w (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, numerals, verbs, adverbs, prepositions, conjunctions, particles)
- wA – archaism  
- wB – poeticism  
- wC – only in corpora  
- wE – expressive  
- wH – conversational  
- wK – bookish  
- wO – regional  
- wR – rare  
- wZ – obsolete  
- wN – dialectal  

Examples:  
- `[tag=".*wH.*"]` – conversational forms.  
- `[tag=".*wZ.*"]` – obsolete forms.

9. Noun subclassification: x (for k1)
- xP – special paradigm type (e.g. půl, čtvrt)  

Example CQL: `[tag="k1xP.*"]` (nouns with special paradigm P).

10. Pronoun subclassification: x, y (for k3)
- xP – personal pronoun  
- xO – possessive pronoun  
- xD – demonstrative pronoun  
- xT – delimitative pronoun  
- yF – reflexive pronoun  
- yQ – interrogative pronoun  
- yR – relative pronoun  
- yN – negative pronoun  
- yI – indeterminate pronoun  

11. Numeral subclassification: x, y (for k4)
- xC – cardinal numeral  
- xO – ordinal numeral  
- xR – “reproductive” numeral  
- yN – negative numeral  
- yI – indeterminate numeral  

12. Verb-specific features: a, m (for k5)
Aspect: a
- aP – perfective  
- aI – imperfective  
- aB – biaspectual  

Verb form / mood / tense: m
- mF – infinitive  
- mI – present indicative  
- mR – imperative  
- mA – past participle (active participle)  
- mN – passive participle (n/t-participle)  
- mS – present transgressive (converb)  
- mD – past transgressive (converb)  
- mB – future indicative  

Example CQL: `[tag="k5aP.*"]` (perfective verbs); `[tag="k5.*mF.*"]` (infinitives).

13. Adverb subclassification: x, y, t (for k6)
Type x (formal subclass):
- xD – demonstrative adverb  
- xT – delimitative adverb  

Type y (functional subclass):
- yQ – interrogative adverb  
- yR – relative adverb  
- yN – negative adverb  
- yI – indeterminate adverb  

Semantic type t (meaning/function of adverb):
- tS – status adverb  
- tD – modal adverb  
- tT – adverb expressing time  
- tA – adverb expressing respect (with regard to something)  
- tC – adverb expressing reason  
- tL – adverb expressing place  
- tM – adverb expressing manner  
- tQ – adverb expressing extent  

Example CQL: `[tag="k6.*tL.*"]` (locative/place adverbs).

14. Conjunction subclassification: x (for k8)
- xC – coordinate conjunction  
- xS – subordinate conjunction  

Example CQL: `[tag="k8xC.*"]` (coordinating conjunctions).

15. Punctuation subclassification: x (for kI)
- x. – sentence-final marks: . ? !  
- x, – separators: , : ;  
- x" – quotation marks: " „ “ ‚ '  
- x( – opening brackets/braces: ( { [ <  
- x) – closing brackets/braces: ) } ] >  
- x~ – other symbols: ~$%^&-_+=|/# etc.  

Example CQL: `[tag="kIx.*"]` then refine by value (e.g. `x."`).

16. Additional / lemma-related or internal feature codes (from “Further tag features”)
These codes are mostly internal or lemma-related; they rarely need to be targeted directly in CQL but may appear in tags. Treat them as literal substrings if necessary.

- rD – internal derivational/inflectional pattern marker (may repeat: `rD,rD,...` etc.; used in complex paradigm descriptions, not normally relevant for basic CQL).
- hT – represents thing (lemma/property flag, often for pronouns/substantives).  
- hP – represents person (lemma/property flag).  
- hF – feminine possessive substantive (SUBST: FEMPOSS).  
- hM – masculine possessive substantive (SUBST: MASKPOSS).  
- hR – “rodina” / family-related; part of possessive-family composite codes.  

Composite patterns (`rD,rD,rD...`) describe sequences of derivational steps (INF, SUBST-i, ADJ-ci, ADJ-ši, ADJ-ý, ADJ-n//-t, etc.). They are highly technical and are best matched with wildcards (e.g. `rD.*`) if ever needed.

SUMMARY OF TAG FORMAT (STRICT)
- Tag structure:  
  `k<POS> [e<negation>] [g<gender>] [n<number>] [c<case>] [p<person>] [a<aspect>] [m<form>] [d<degree>] [x<subtype1>] [y<subtype2>] [t<adv_type>] [z<other>] [w<style>] [~<other2>]`  
  where each square-bracketed segment is optional but, if present, must appear in this order.
- Each attribute–value pair is exactly 2 characters: one lowercase attribute letter + one uppercase letter, digit, or symbol (for punctuation subclasses).
- No separators or spaces inside the tag.
- CQL must respect this strict order: if you specify multiple attributes in the regex, put them in canonical order and use `.*` to skip unknown/intervening attributes.

how CQL with tagset should be writtem
=====================================

- Basic token query:
  - Use positional attributes in square brackets, with values in straight double quotes.
  - Example: [tag="NNS"] finds plural common nouns.
  - Attribute names: word, tag, lemma, lemma_lc, lempos, lc.
- Tag format and strictness:
  - tag must have format exactly as in the tagset list (below).
  - Tags are case-sensitive and must match strictly (e.g. "NN", not "nn"; "IN/that" with slash; "VBZ", not "Vbz").
  - Punctuation tags are also strict: e.g. [tag="."] is wrong; you must use [tag="SENT"] for sentence-final punctuation, [tag=","] for comma, [tag=":"] for dash/colon/semicolon-type punctuation, [tag="("] and [tag=")"] for brackets, [tag="\""] or [tag="``"] exactly as defined below, [tag="#"], [tag="$"].
- Regular expressions on tags:
  - You can use regex on tag, e.g.:
    - [tag="N.*"] – any noun (NN, NNS, NP, NPS).
    - [tag="J.*"] – any adjective (JJ, JJR, JJS).
    - [tag="RB.?"] – any adverb (RB, RBR, RBS).
    - [tag="V.*"] – any verb of any series (VB, VBD, VVG, VVZ, VH*, VV* etc.).
  - Predefined functional “annotations” correspond to regexes on tag:
    - adjective  → tag="J.*"
    - adverb     → tag="RB.?"
    - conjunction→ tag="CC"
    - determiner → tag="DT"
    - noun       → tag="N.*"
    - numeral    → tag="CD"
    - particle   → tag="RP"
    - preposition→ tag="IN"
    - pronoun    → tag="PP.?"
    - verb       → tag="V.*"
- Lemma and lempos:
  - lemma: [lemma="run"] matches lemma “run” for all POS.
  - lempos combines lemma and a one-letter POS suffix:
    - adjective → -j
    - adverb    → -a
    - conjunction → -c
    - noun      → -n
    - preposition → -i
    - pronoun   → -p
    - verb      → -v
  - Example CQL:
    - [lempos="run-v"] – verb uses of “run”.
    - [lempos="good-j"] – adjective “good”.
    - [lempos="in-i"] – prepositional “in”.
- Examples of CQL usage with tagset and attributes:
  - Adjective followed by noun: [tag="J.*"] [tag="N.*"]
  - “to” as infinitive marker followed by base-form verb: [word="to" & tag="TO"] [tag="VV"]
  - Noun lemma “table” in plural: [lemma="table" & tag="NNS"]
  - Any pronoun subject followed by a finite verb: [tag="PP.?"] [tag="VVP|VVZ|VHP|VHZ|VBP|VBZ"]
- Structural constraints in CQL:
  - Limit to within sentences: use the “within” parameter (<s>) in the interface, or rely on SENT tags for end-of-sentence punctuation.
  - Paragraph/sentence boundaries etc. are accessible via structures:
    - e.g. “within <s/>” (Sketch Engine interface) or “within <p/>” etc.
  - Document, chapter, speaker attributes are usable in text-type filters (not directly inside [] token patterns) to restrict which texts are searched.

the tagset
==========

Tag values must be used exactly as listed below; they are strict, case-sensitive, and include punctuation and special forms. Each line explains the function of that tag.

CC – coordinating conjunction (and, or, but)
CD – cardinal number (1, 2, third)
DT – determiner (the, a, this)
EX – existential there (there in “there is/are”)
FW – foreign word (les, etc.)
IN – preposition or subordinating conjunction (in, of, like, because)
IN/that – “that” used as a subordinator (that introducing a clause)
JJ – adjective, base (green)
JJR – adjective, comparative (greener)
JJS – adjective, superlative (greenest)
LS – list marker (1), a., i), etc.)
MD – modal auxiliary (can, could, will, would, may, might, must, shall, should)
NN – common noun, singular or mass (table, milk)
NNS – common noun, plural (tables)
NP – proper noun, singular (John, London)
NPS – proper noun, plural (Vikings, the Smiths)
PDT – predeterminer (both in “both the boys”)
POS – possessive ending (’s or ’ in English, as separate token)
PP – personal pronoun (I, he, it, we, they, you, me, him, them)
PPZ – possessive pronoun (my, his, their, our, your, its)
RB – adverb, base (however, usually, naturally, here, well)
RBR – adverb, comparative (better, more quickly)
RBS – adverb, superlative (best, most quickly)
RP – particle (up in “give up”, out in “find out”)
SENT – sentence-break punctuation (. ! ? as end-of-sentence marker)
SYM – symbol (/, [, =, *, mathematical symbols, etc.)
TO – infinitive marker to (to in “to go”; distinct from IN when preposition)
UH – interjection (uh, uhhuhhuhh, wow, oh)
VB – verb “be”, base form (be)
VBD – verb “be”, past tense (was, were)
VBG – verb “be”, gerund/present participle (being)
VBN – verb “be”, past participle (been)
VBP – verb “be”, present tense, non-3rd singular (am, are)
VBZ – verb “be”, 3rd person singular present (is)
VH – verb “have”, base form (have)
VHD – verb “have”, past tense (had)
VHG – verb “have”, gerund/present participle (having)
VHN – verb “have”, past participle (had)
VHP – verb “have”, present tense, non-3rd singular (have)
VHZ – verb “have”, 3rd person singular present (has)
VV – other (non-modal) lexical verb, base form (take, run, see)
VVD – lexical verb, past tense (took, ran, saw)
VVG – lexical verb, gerund/present participle (taking, running, seeing)
VVN – lexical verb, past participle (taken, run, seen)
VVP – lexical verb, present tense, non-3rd singular (take, run)
VVZ – lexical verb, 3rd person singular present (takes, runs)
WDT – wh-determiner (which, that in some interrogative/relative uses)
WP – wh-pronoun (who, what)
WP$ – possessive wh-pronoun (whose)
WRB – wh-adverb (where, when, why, how)
# – hash symbol (# as token)
$ – currency symbol ($ as token)
" – quotation marks (single or double quotes as a generic quote token)
`` – opening quotation marks (opening quote form; used by TreeTagger/Sketch for opening quotes)
( – opening brackets ( ( or { )
) – closing brackets ( ) or } )
, – comma (,)
: – other punctuation (colon, semicolon, dash, ellipsis, etc.)

Remember: when writing CQL, use these tag strings exactly as shown (including punctuation and any slashes), inside double quotes after tag=, e.g. [tag="NP"], [tag="IN/that"], [tag=","], [tag="SENT"].
